Hi Mridul, it looks like what you are trying to do is just cause NEAT 
to a=
ssign a weight of zero to every weight.  Is that the goal?

What inputs are=
 you sending in?  Are they deterministic or stochastic 
for each individual=
 who is being evaluated?  It is relevant because 
the outputs depend on the=
 input.

I dont know Mat Buckland's code, but I am not sure that an index 
=
above 1 is possible.  Usually, sigmoid activation functions max out 
at 1. =
 So your final case may never occur.

You also only assign fitness to integ=
er outputs.  Neural networks 
often output numbers between zero and one.  T=
herefore, it appears 
your fitness assignment does not assign any value for=
 scalar values 
between zero and one, which may throw off your fitness assi=
gnment 
scheme.  You may need to consider a continuous function that assign=
s 
fitness on a sliding scale.

ken

 Learning algorithm against 
NEAT, and I'm trying to test NEAT in a simple =
domain.

> 
> Irrespective of the input =
value, the fitness is calculated by:
> 
> index =3D argmax(outputs)
> if (i=
ndex =3D 0)

> if (index =3D 1)

> i=
f (index =3D=3D 2) or (index =3D=3D 3)

>

att Buckland's windowsNeat code to test this, and I 
find that the total ut=
ility increases to a certain point & then

 conclude that learning has occurred?
